tipp.name: Temperature Change
tipp.description: Quickly changing your body temperature can help regulate intense emotions.
steps: Place your face in a bowl of cold water, or hold a cold pack (or wrapped ice) on your eyes and cheeks
Hold your breath (if comfortable) for 30 seconds
Keep the cold water/ice on your face for at least 30 seconds
This activates the 'diving reflex' which can rapidly calm your body
tipp.when_to_use: When experiencing overwhelming urges, anger, or distress

tipp.name: Intense Exercise
tipp.description: Brief, intense physical activity to release built-up energy and stress.
steps: Choose an activity that gets your heart rate up quickly (jumping jacks, running in place, push-ups)
Exercise intensely for 1-2 minutes
Focus on your breathing and the physical sensations in your body
Continue until you feel a shift in your emotional state
tipp.when_to_use: When feeling agitated, anxious, or having cravings

tipp.name: Paced Breathing
tipp.description: Slow, deep breathing to activate the parasympathetic nervous system.
steps: Breathe in slowly through your nose for 4 counts
Hold for 2 counts
Exhale slowly through your mouth for 6 counts
Repeat for at least 2 minutes
Focus on making your exhale longer than your inhale
tipp.when_to_use: Any time you need to calm down, especially before meetings or stressful situations

tipp.name: Progressive Muscle Relaxation
tipp.description: Systematically tensing and relaxing different muscle groups to reduce physical tension.
steps: Get in a comfortable position
Tense the muscles in your feet for 5-10 seconds, then release
Notice the difference between tension and relaxation
Work your way up through your body: calves, thighs, abdomen, hands, arms, shoulders, neck, face
Tense each muscle group for 5-10 seconds, then release
tipp.when_to_use: When physically tense, before bed, or when experiencing cravings

thought_records.name: Basic Thought Record
thought_records.description: A simple tool to identify and challenge unhelpful thoughts.
fields: Situation: What happened? When? Where? Who with?
Emotions: What did you feel? Rate intensity 0-100%
Automatic Thoughts: What went through your mind? What did these thoughts mean?
Evidence For: What facts support this thought?
Evidence Against: What facts don't support this thought?
Alternative Perspective: What's another way to look at this?
Outcome: How do you feel now? What could you do?
thought_records.when_to_use: When caught in negative thinking patterns or before/after high-risk situations

thought_records.name: Urge Surfing Log
thought_records.description: Track and ride out cravings without acting on them.
fields: Trigger: What set off the craving?
Physical Sensations: What do you feel in your body?
Thoughts: What thoughts accompany the craving?
Actions Taken: What did you do instead of drinking?
How long did the urge last?
thought_records.when_to_use: When experiencing cravings or urges to drink

thought_records.name: HALT Check
thought_records.description: Quick assessment to identify basic needs that might be triggering urges.
fields: Hungry? When did you last eat? Do you need nourishment?
Angry? What's bothering you? Who do you need to talk to?
Lonely? Who could you connect with? When did you last attend a meeting?
Tired? How has your sleep been? Do you need rest or a break?
thought_records.when_to_use: When feeling irritable, off-balance, or experiencing cravings

breathing_exercises.name: 4-7-8 Breathing
breathing_exercises.description: A breathing pattern that promotes relaxation.
steps: Sit or lie comfortably with your back straight
Place the tip of your tongue against the ridge of tissue behind your upper front teeth
Exhale completely through your mouth, making a whoosh sound
Close your mouth and inhale quietly through your nose to a count of 4
Hold your breath for a count of 7
Exhale completely through your mouth, making a whoosh sound, to a count of 8
Repeat the cycle 3-4 times
breathing_exercises.when_to_use: When anxious, before bed, or during stressful situations

breathing_exercises.name: Box Breathing
breathing_exercises.description: Equal-timed breathing pattern to promote calm and focus.
steps: Sit with your back straight
Exhale completely
Inhale through your nose for 4 counts
Hold your breath for 4 counts
Exhale through your mouth for 4 counts
Hold your breath for 4 counts
Repeat for 4-5 cycles
breathing_exercises.when_to_use: Before meetings, during cravings, or when feeling overwhelmed

breathing_exercises.name: Alternate Nostril Breathing
breathing_exercises.description: A yogic breathing technique to balance energy and calm the mind.
steps: Sit comfortably with your back straight
Place your left hand on your left knee
Lift your right hand toward your nose
Use your right thumb to close your right nostril
Inhale deeply through your left nostril
Close your left nostril with your right ring finger
Release your thumb and exhale through your right nostril
Inhale through your right nostril
Close it with your thumb, release your ring finger, and exhale through your left nostril
Continue this pattern for 5-10 cycles
breathing_exercises.when_to_use: When feeling unbalanced or experiencing racing thoughts

grounding_techniques.name: 5-4-3-2-1 Technique
grounding_techniques.description: Sensory awareness exercise to bring you back to the present moment.
steps: Notice 5 things you can see
Notice 4 things you can feel/touch
Notice 3 things you can hear
Notice 2 things you can smell (or like the smell of)
Notice 1 thing you can taste (or like the taste of)
grounding_techniques.when_to_use: When experiencing anxiety, cravings, or feeling disconnected

grounding_techniques.name: Body Scan
grounding_techniques.description: A mindfulness practice to reconnect with your body.
steps: Lie down or sit comfortably
Close your eyes and take a few deep breaths
Bring your awareness to your feet, noticing any sensations
Slowly move your attention up through your body: legs, hips, abdomen, chest, back, shoulders, arms, hands, neck, face
For each area, notice sensations without judgment
If you notice tension, breathe into that area and imagine releasing it
grounding_techniques.when_to_use: When feeling disconnected from your body or experiencing cravings

grounding_techniques.name: Object Focus
grounding_techniques.description: Intensely focus on a single object to anchor yourself in the present.
steps: Choose any object nearby
Examine it with full attention for 1-2 minutes
Notice its color, texture, weight, temperature, patterns, shape
If your mind wanders, gently bring your focus back to the object
Describe the object to yourself in detail
grounding_techniques.when_to_use: When experiencing racing thoughts or strong emotions

urge_surfing.name: Urge Surfing Meditation
urge_surfing.description: A mindfulness practice specifically for riding out cravings.
steps: Find a comfortable position and close your eyes
Notice the craving or urge in your body - where do you feel it?
Observe the sensation with curiosity, not judgment
Notice its shape, intensity, temperature, movement
Breathe into the sensation
Remind yourself that urges are like waves - they rise, peak, and eventually fall
Continue observing the sensation as it changes
Remind yourself that you don't need to act on this urge
Stay with the process until the intensity decreases
urge_surfing.when_to_use: When experiencing strong cravings or urges to drink

urge_surfing.name: Quick Urge Delay
urge_surfing.description: Simple technique to create space between urge and action.
steps: When you notice an urge, pause
Take 10 slow, deep breaths
Remind yourself: 'This is just an urge. It will pass.'
Commit to waiting 15 minutes before deciding
Distract yourself with an activity during those 15 minutes
After waiting, reassess if you still want to act on the urge
urge_surfing.when_to_use: When experiencing sudden or intense urges

acceptance_practices.name: Acceptance Statement Practice
acceptance_practices.description: Practice accepting what you cannot change.
steps: Identify something you're struggling to accept
Write or say: 'I'm having difficulty accepting [situation/feeling/thought]'
Take a deep breath and then say: 'I cannot change [situation]'
Repeat: 'I accept that this is the reality right now'
Add: 'I can still take positive action despite this reality'
Finish with: 'I choose to focus on what I can control'
acceptance_practices.when_to_use: When struggling with resentment or things you cannot change

acceptance_practices.name: Letting Go Visualization
acceptance_practices.description: Visualize releasing things you cannot control.
steps: Sit comfortably and close your eyes
Identify a resentment, regret, or struggle you're holding onto
Imagine placing this burden in a container (box, balloon, leaf on a stream)
Visualize releasing the container (sending the balloon into the sky, watching the leaf float downstream)
Say to yourself: 'I release this. It no longer serves me.'
Take a deep breath and feel the sense of lightness
acceptance_practices.when_to_use: When holding onto resentments or painful memories
